events.originalText: The evacuation of nearly 88,000 people began when a wildfire swept through Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada, and burned for another 14 months, becoming the costliest disaster in Canadian history.
events.subtitle: 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire
events.headline: Wildfire in Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada forces evacuation of 88,000 people

events.originalText: In Major League Baseball, Rickey Henderson broke the record for stolen bases on the same night that Nolan Ryan broke his own record for no-hitters.
events.subtitle: Major League Baseball
events.headline: Rickey Henderson and Nolan Ryan break records in Major League Baseball

events.originalText: Argentine president Juan Perón expelled Montoneros from a demonstration in the Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires, forcing the group to become a clandestine organization.
events.subtitle: Juan Perón
events.headline: Argentine president Juan Perón expels Montoneros from Plaza de Mayo demonstration

events.originalText: Gwendolyn Brooks became the first African American to receive the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry.
events.subtitle: Gwendolyn Brooks
events.headline: Gwendolyn Brooks first African American to win Pulitzer Prize for Poetry

events.originalText: Sicilian separatist Salvatore Giuliano and his gang fired into a crowd of May Day marchers near Piana degli Albanesi, Sicily, killing 11 and wounding 33.
events.subtitle: Salvatore Giuliano
events.headline: Sicilian separatist Salvatore Giuliano kills 11 in May Day shooting

events.originalText: Second World War: British and Indian forces conducted a successful airborne assault on a Japanese artillery battery during the advance to liberate Rangoon, Burma.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: British and Indian forces conduct successful airborne assault in Burma during WWII

events.originalText: Citizen Kane, a widely acclaimed film by actor and director Orson Welles, premiered.
events.subtitle: Citizen Kane
events.headline: Orson Welles' Citizen Kane premieres to critical acclaim

events.originalText: New York City's Empire State Building, at the time the tallest building in the world, opened.
events.subtitle: Empire State Building
events.headline: Empire State Building opens in New York City as tallest building in the world

events.originalText: A dust explosion at a coal mine near Scofield, Utah, U.S., killed at least 200 miners.
events.subtitle: Dust explosion
events.headline: Coal mine explosion in Scofield, Utah kills at least 200 miners

events.originalText: The original Chicago Board of Trade Building opened for business.
events.subtitle: Chicago Board of Trade Building
events.headline: Moses Fleetwood Walker plays first game in Major League Baseball

events.originalText: Moses Fleetwood Walker (pictured), the last African American in Major League Baseball until Jackie Robinson, played his first game for the Toledo Blue Stockings.
events.subtitle: Moses Fleetwood Walker
events.headline: France regains lost land in War of the Pyrenees

events.originalText: War of the Pyrenees: France regained nearly all the land it lost to Spain the previous year with its victory in the Second Battle of Boulou.
events.subtitle: War of the Pyrenees
events.headline: Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro premieres in Vienna

events.originalText: The Marriage of Figaro (audio featured), an opera buffa by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, premiered at the Burgtheater in Vienna.
events.subtitle: The Marriage of Figaro
events.headline: Order of Illuminati founded in Ingolstadt, Bavaria, Germany

events.originalText: The secret society known as the Order of Illuminati was founded by Adam Weishaupt and Adolph Freiherr Knigge in Ingolstadt, Bavaria, Germany.
events.subtitle: Secret society
events.headline: Kingdom of Great Britain formed under Acts of Union

events.originalText: Under the terms of the Acts of Union, the Kingdoms of England and Scotland merged to form the Kingdom of Great Britain, with a single parliament and government based in Westminster.
events.subtitle: Acts of Union 1707
events.headline: Portuguese and Spanish forces recapture Bahia from Dutch Republic

events.originalText: Dutch–Portuguese War: Portuguese and Spanish forces recaptured the Brazilian city of Bahia, which had previously been captured by the Dutch Republic.
events.subtitle: Dutch–Portuguese War
events.headline: Stephen Báthory and Anna Jagiellon crowned rulers of Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth

events.originalText: Stephen Báthory and Anna Jagiellon were crowned as the elected rulers of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
events.subtitle: Stephen Báthory
events.headline: Nea Ekklesia church consecrated in Constantinople

events.originalText: The Nea Ekklesia church in Constantinople, on which many later cross-in-square Orthodox churches were based, was consecrated.
events.subtitle: Nea Ekklesia
events.headline: Diocletian and Maximian retire as co-rulers of Roman Empire

events.originalText: Diocletian and  Maximian retired as co-rulers of the Roman Empire, being succeeded by Galerius and Constantius Chlorus.
events.subtitle: Diocletian
